title: War and Peace's James Norton makes a cliffhanging comeback
title_page: War and Peace's James Norton makes a cliffhanging comeback | Daily Mail Online
text:
With his chiselled cheek bones and smouldering good looks, James Norton has quickly become War and Peace’s heartthrob.
But women across the country were in for a traumatic watch last night as viewers of the show were led to believe that his character had been killed.
Fans watched on in horror as Prince Andrei Bolkonsky dismounted his horse, picking up the standard, before charging at the French, during the second episode of the programme.
Scroll down for video
Fans watched on in horror as Prince Andrei Bolkonsky dismounted his horse and charged at the French during last night's episode of War and Peace. Viewers were shocked to see him stabbed in the side, appearing dead
With viewers believing the young prince was dead, just minutes from the end of the episode he stepped out of a carriage alive and well - arriving just in time for the birth of his child (pictured). However, tragically his wife dies
Just seconds after his heroic efforts begin, halfway through the episode, the handsome Prince is violently stabbed in the side, causing him to collapse on the floor.
His blooded body remains amongst hundreds of dead Russians, with French troops commenting: ‘He looks like a fine young man. Good way to die, carrying the standard.’
The young prince’s heartbroken family even receive a letter telling them he is presumed dead, though his name has not yet appeared amongst the deceased.
But just minutes from the end of the episode, his sister, Princess Marya Bolkonskaya, spots a horse-drawn carriage arriving at the driveway of their home.
Nikolai Rostov appeared on horseback in the second episode of last night's BBC drama, War and Peace
Prince Andrei struts his stuff in War and Peace during an episode which saw him almost killed off after heroics
The family, and no doubt swooning female viewers, were delighted when the Prince steps out of the carriage very much alive and seemingly uninjured.
He arrived just in time for the birth of his child, though tragically his wife, Lise Bolkonsky, passes away during childbirth.
Based on Leo Tolstoy’s novel, War and Peace, the story is one of love, loss and politics among the Russian aristocracy, all set against a backdrop of the Napoleonic Wars.
It is this conflict that provided much of the drama for episode two, which was shown on BBC One last night.
